awd_titl_txt: The International Global Atmospheric Chemistry (IGAC) International Project Office (IPO)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports the International Project Office (IPO) of the International Global Atmospheric Chemistry (IGAC) Project, a project of the international Commission on Atmospheric Composition and Global Pollution and a Global Research Project under the umbrella of Future Earth.  The three focal areas of IGAC activity are (1) Fostering Community, (2) Building Capacity, and (3) Providing Leadership.  The IGAC IPO facilitates international scientific collaborations, cultivates the next generation of scientists, builds capacity in developing countries, and fosters a cohesive international community of atmospheric scientists working together across disciplines and geographical boundaries to address global change and sustainability issues.

IGAC's priorities and activities are determined and guided by an international volunteer Scientific Steering Committee (SSC).  The main responsibility of the IGAC International Project Office's (IPO) is to implement these priorities in collaboration with SSC members and other members of the international atmospheric chemistry community.  The responsibilities of the IPO include: administering projects on a day-to-day basis under the guidance of the SSC; supporting the SSC in planning and carrying out IGAC's mission and goals; working with the SSC and the community on coordinating IGAC activities and national and regional working groups; serving as a channel of communication between scientists working in different countries on various aspects of global change and sustainability; organizing events, workshops, and capacity building activities; promoting IGAC activities and events via newsletters, email lists, website, social media, presentations, etc.; interacting with relevant policy and stakeholder communities; serving as liaison with scientific sponsors, funding agencies and host institutions; and creating and maintaining an archive of key core project documents.  For developing country scientists, IGAC fosters the creation of a strong cohesive community of atmospheric scientists in under-represented regions of the world and also connects the scientists to the larger IGAC community in order to foster international collaborations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Estabilished in 1990 as a core project of the International GLobal Biosphere Geosphere Project and currently a Global Research Network under Future Earth, The International Global Atmospheric Chemistry (IGAC) Project was founded to facility community building at the international level to address pressing atmospheric chemistry issues that need international (multi-nation) cooperation to address and global (beyond any geographic boundary) collaboration to understand. The IGAC Project is free to join and open to all atmospheric chemists in any career stage.

The project seeks to 'advance atmospheric chemistry towards a sustainable world'. We do this by advancing knowledge through scientific activities and global collaborations, fostering community with conferences, activities, regional working groups, and communication, and building capacity with early career researcher programs, an early career steering committee, and regional working groups. We strive to engage society in our work and are exploring effective methods to do this. 

The IGAC Project is run by an international Scientific Steering Committee (SSC), chosen by application and with the goal of having regional, expertise, and gender balance. Members must rotate off after 6 years to keep the SSC from stagnating. The SSC discusses and decides on IGAC priorities at annual in-person meetings and thrice-yearly virtual meetings. The SSC also at times writes positioning papers on international atmospheric chemistry issues (such as a recent comment on the new World Health Organization air quality standards). 

Major outcomes from the IGAC Project included the community-driven scientific activities that bring together international scientists around pressuing atmospheric chemistry issues (e.g., tropospheric ozone globally, global emissions inventories, the cryosphere and atmospheric chemistry, air pollution in the arctic, atmospheric composition and the asian monsoon, biomass burning uncertainties, and others). These activities host open science meetings and summer schools for sharing knowledge and building capacity. 

Regional working group developments were another outcome of the IGAC project. These are community-led groups centered around regional networking and fostering community both within the region, and connecting these regional communities to the international atmospheric chemistry community. As issues of air pollution and biomass burning emissions becomes more global, more global scientists are needed to address these issues and IGAC seeks to find these scientists. These working groups host summer schools, trainings, write review papers (such as a paper on atmospheric chemistry issues in the Southern Hemisphere), and do outreach such as journalist trainings or inviting policy makers to their meetings for open dialogue and discussion. 

While regional working groups and activities have events throughout the year, the biennial international IGAC conference is the major event for the IGAC Project. In September 2021, during COVID-19 restrictions on travel, IGAC held its first virtual conference. This conference focused on the science of the regional activities and working groups and had both plenary sessions and virtual poster sessions. Over 900 people registered for the conference, from 90 countries. In September 2022, the conference took place in hybrid format in Manchester, UK and globally virtually. The conference had ~400 attendees (~280 in-person and over 120 virtual), almost half of which were early career researchers, and 38 countries were represented at the conference. Three days before this conference, a 39 person Early Career Short Course took place. The Early Career Short Course was planned solely by a committee of early career scientists, contained networking and instructional courses, and was made up of an international group of scientists chosen from a group of over 100 applicants. In exit surveys, participants stated that they felt as if they 'made a network for life' and many have gone on to join other IGAC working groups and activities, or the newly-established IGAC early career Scientific Steering Committee.  

IGAC is part of Future Earth, an international sustainability science organization that sponsores a number of research networks focused on sustainability science. Future Earth provides a platform for connecting the breadth of topics needed to be incoporated in any discussion of sustainability, while the individual networks provide the depth needed for full understanding of these topics. In 2021 and 2022, IGAC organized several transdisciplinary sessions on sustainability at the Future Earth and Belmont Forum sponsored Sustainability Research and Innovation (SRI) conference. Sessions included one on a JUST energy transition (including industry, academia, and environmental justice experts), incoperating the atmopshere into the sustainability development goals (SDGs), and others). 

The underlying purpose of IGAC is to build international atmospheric chemistry community. This can be a somewhat intangible goal with hard to quantify outcomes, but the successful regional working groups and activities, the well-attended and engagement-heavy conferences, workshops, and summer schools,  and the growing early career community, demonstrates that IGAC remains an effective way to build atmospheric chemistry community.  IGAC brings together different voices and perspectives in the community that can go on to tackle, together, challenges in atmospheric chemistry.
